<details><summary>Excercise 3</summary>

Get the prevalence to 100,000 people

$$
Prevalence = \frac{1,500 \times 100,000}{3,000,000}= 50 \text{ cases per 100,000}
$$

$$
\text{\% New cases}= \frac{10}{50} = 0.2 \times 100 = 20\%
$$

</details>



<details><summary>Excercise 4</summary>

We now that:

$$
Prevalence = Incidence \times \text{Duration of the disease}
$$

Then,

$$
Prevalence = \text{12 per 100,000 people anually} \times \text{0.5 years} = \text{6 cases per 100,000 people }
$$

</details>
